awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Mechanisms of adaptation to saltwater by an amphibian
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the genetic and cellular processes that allow some populations of the American green tree frog (Hyla cinerea) to tolerate high salt concentrations, and how saltwater affects the natural history of amphibians. The ongoing decline of habitat quality and quantity has increased the urgency to understand how organisms adapt to new or changing environments. Evolution might occur rapidly and quickly enough to rescue populations and protect species from being lost in the face of a changing environment, including by the increasing salinization of freshwater wetlands around the world. As wetlands grow saltier, many freshwater wetland organisms such as fish, turtles, and frogs may become locally extinct. However, populations of the American green tree frog have been discovered in brackish wetlands. This project will compare frogs from coastal and inland populations for differences in gene expression, egg hatching, and larval development, among other traits. The results will lead to a much better understanding of the process of adaptation to saline environments. In addition, the project will engage with K-12 students, especially those from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences.

To determine whether putatively salt-tolerant frog populations are adaptively diverging from freshwater populations in response to salt exposure, this study uses a common garden, factorial design to investigate endpoints across multiple levels of biological organization across three stages of anuran amphibian development (egg, larval, and post metamorphosis). The study will characterize transcriptomic responses following saltwater exposure and relate these patterns to subsequent protein expression and fitness correlates (e.g., developmental rates, survival). In doing so, the project links selective pressures occurring at the level of the whole organism to the molecular processes that underlie adaptation. The project will identify the mechanisms that underlie salt tolerance and differentiate between competing hypotheses about the role of genetic variation and plasticity in the evolution of adaptive change.

por.por_cntn:
Global environmental change is degrading the integrity, quality, and functioning of ecosystems worldwide. Predicting the future resilience of ecosystems to ongoing change depends on understanding whether constituent species will adapt to changing conditions or be extirpated. Our ability to predict adaptive responses in wild organisms is limited because we do not fully understand how environmental change will interact with organismal traits like phenotypic plasticity or gene expression to affect adaptation. Adaptive phenotypic plasticity occurs when a genotype can express alternative phenotypes that improve fitness across variable environments and can either drive or inhibit evolutionary adaptation in response to variable and changing environments. The goals of this grant were to explore the role of phenotypic plasticity in generating adaptive phenotypes, and also to characterize physiological and life historical patterns demonstrating adaptation to salinity in an amphibian living in coastal wetland habitats. To accomplish this goal, we employed experimental and statistical techniques to characterize developmental, transcriptional, proteomic, and fitness responses to saltwater exposure and relate these patterns to subsequent protein expression and fitness correlates (e.g., developmental rates, survival, etc.), thereby linking selective pressures at the whole organism to the molecular processes that underlie adaptation.

We show evidence that coastal H. cinerea frog populations are adaptively diverging from inland counterparts through shifted developmental trait means consistent with the Baldwin’s effect. Evolution via Baldwin’s effect is expected in highly variable environments, which matches the highly variable salinities observed in coastal wetlands. Collectively, these data suggest that coastal frogs are accelerating the larval period and are shifting their life history strategy to reduce time spent in a highly variable, unpredictable, and stressful environment such as those typical of coastal wetlands. Additionally. we have identified molecular mechanisms that may underlie salt tolerance in wild populations of frogs. We found that 1,924 genes are differentially expressed between coastal and inland populations, while just 267 genes are differentially expressed across different salinity exposures, showing clear divergence in gene expression across coastal and inland locations that cannot be explained by saltwater exposure during development. Moreover, individuals from coastal populations have higher tadpole survival and higher plasma osmolality which are likely correlated with differences in gene expression. The genes that emerged as different between coastal and inland populations translate into diverse molecular functions but include several genes that encode cellular transporter proteins and stress response pathways.

Our results reveal the molecular signatures of saltwater tolerance in coastal frog populations and support the hypothesis that coastal populations of Hyla cinerea are locally adapted to brackish environments. Furthermore, we demonstrate that plasticity may be a more common mechanism of adaptation than presently appreciated and highlights the growing necessity to test how phenotypic plasticity and environmental stochasticity affect adaptation to global environmental change.
